title: Barr Kept Hunter Biden Probes From Public View
summary: The attorney general knew for months about investigations into Biden's business and financial dealings. Attorney General William Barr has known about a disparate set of investigations involving Hunter Biden's business and financial dealings since at least this spring, a person familiar with the matter said, and worked to avoid their public disclosure during the heated election campaign.

title: U.S., EU to Impose Sanctions on Turkey Over Missile System, Energy
summary: EU stopped short of adopting the broader economic sanctions against Ankara requested by some of its members. The U.S. and European Union are applying pressure on Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, with Washington planning sanctions over Turkey's acquisition of a Russian air-defense system and the EU targeting people involved in Ankara's energy exploration activities in the eastern Mediterranean.

title: Disney+ Could Hit 260 Million Subscribers by 2024, CEO Bob Chapek Says
summary: Streaming service has 86.8 million subscribers globally. Walt Disney Co. 's flagship streaming service Disney+ is growing at such a clip that the company's world-wide subscriber count could triple to 260 million by 2024, the company said Thursday.

title: GOP Leaders See Bipartisan Group's Covid-Aid Effort Falling Short
summary: Coalition has been working to reach a compromise on state and local aid, liability shield. WASHINGTON-Top Senate Republicans signaled Thursday they wouldn't accept a bipartisan group's efforts to craft a compromise on state and local governments and liability protections during the pandemic, undercutting the coalition's attempt to break the months-long impasse over a coronavirus relief package.

title: Justices Rule for Muslim Men Who Sued FBI Agents
summary: The men alleged religious retaliation after they refused to cooperate with counterterrorism cases. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court ruled Thursday that federal agents can be sued for putting Muslim men on the no-fly list in alleged retaliation for their refusal to cooperate with counterterrorism investigations.

title: Facebook Lawsuits Take Aim at Data-Sharing Tool Key to Digital Economy
summary: In the spotlight: The glue binding big software platforms to users. Dueling antitrust lawsuits against Facebook Inc. highlighted the social-media giant's acquisitions of photo-sharing platform Instagram and messaging service WhatsApp.

title: Covid-19 Vaccine Candidate Scrapped After False Positives on HIV Tests
summary: Australia had ordered 51 million doses of vaccine under joint development by CSL Ltd., University of Queensland. SYDNEY-A Covid-19 vaccine candidate in Australia has been scrapped because recipients returned false positives on certain HIV tests, underscoring the difficulties scientists face in rapidly developing an inoculation for the coronavirus.

title: Broadcom Elevates Accounting Chief to CFO
summary: The chip maker's current finance chief will run a new group overseeing software operations. Broadcom Inc. elevated its controller and chief accounting officer to the role of finance chief as part of a series of management changes at the semiconductor firm.

title: Breaking Up Facebook
summary: The feds want a do-over for acquisitions they previously approved.. Facebook 's motto in its early days was to "move fast and break things." That's also one way to describe the Federal Trade Commission lawsuit against Facebook that was seconded this week by 46 state Attorneys General. That so many lawyers could come up with such a weak legal case is remarkable.

title: AOC's Latest Achievement
summary: Goya honors Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez as Employee of the Month.. Guess who's Goya's "Employee of the Month?" The honor goes to Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez (D., N.Y.), who famously supported the boycott of Goya Foods earlier this year after CEO Robert Unanue visited the Trump White House as part of a Hispanic Prosperity Initiative.

title: Texas Tries an Election Long Shot
summary: Can a state be harmed by the way other states conduct their elections?. Ken Paxton, the Texas Attorney General, seems intent on developing a name for himself as the patron saint of lost legal causes. He's the father of the recent and long-shot case against ObamaCare, and this week he launched another implausible appeal to the U.S. Supreme Court to overturn state presidential election results.

title: The Hunter Biden Business
summary: The story the press ignored returns in time for Joe's Presidency.. So Hunter Biden's business is news after all. Who knew? Well, the New York Post did, and so did we and a few others.

title: Mrs. Smith's Tips for New Lawmakers
summary: As Washington readies for the 117th Congress, its members can learn from a 20th-century great.. I want to stick with Margaret Chase Smith this week, in part because I can't get my mind off her and in part because we have a new Congress coming in, the 117th, to be sworn in on Jan. 3, and its members could benefit from Smith's rules of the road. She was the first senator of either party to stand up to Joe McCarthy. Her fellow Republicans scrammed: McCarthy was popular back home. So did Democrats; they feared McCarthy too. What she'd done and suffered through made her name. History appreciated her, and so did flinty, independent Maine.

title: India Throws a Trudeau Tantrum
summary: Sikh separatist history and Canadian domestic politics fuel a transoceanic dispute.. Justin Trudeau may have a fan following in North America. But for the Indian government, the Canadian prime minister is a massive pain in the neck. No other Western politician creates so much friction.

title: Costco Keeps Drawing Homebound Shoppers
summary: Comparable sales jump 17% in the latest quarter as Americans spend more on food, appliances and homegoods. Costco Wholesale Corp. reported strong quarterly sales Thursday as homebound Americans continue to spend more on food, homegoods and fitness products during the pandemic, especially the high-income shoppers that make up much of the warehouse chain's shopper base.

title: Facebook Case Presents Test for Antitrust Enforcement, Federal Courts
summary: Judiciary will have the last word on bipartisan allegations that Facebook illegally maintains a monopoly. The sweeping government antitrust lawsuits against Facebook Inc. laid down a new bipartisan marker for enforcement after years of hesitancy, but they will be tested by a federal court system that has proved skeptical of broad antitrust intervention.

title: Treasury Provides More Clarity on Banks' Sharing Information
summary: Guidance attempts to clarify limits on information-sharing partnerships established under the 2001 Patriot Act. The U.S.'s anti-money-laundering watchdog released new guidance Thursday on how financial institutions can share personally identifiable information about their customers if they believe it is tied to a suspicious transaction.

title: A Shot (Instead of Two) at Saving Lives
summary: Waiting on the Covid booster would allow more people to be vaccinated sooner.. Recent days brought good news and bad news about coronavirus vaccines. The developments could add up to months of delay in getting most Americans inoculated. But there's a way to make use of the good news to speed up herd immunity.

title: Now Is as Good a Time as Any for the U.S. to Quit Afghanistan
summary: Whether American forces stay or leave, the fighting is guaranteed to continue. Why not cut our losses?. It was the shot of a lifetime. A lone Taliban fighter, armed with a cheap rocket-propelled grenade launcher, had destroyed the enormous surveillance blimp tethered to our patrol base. The $500 rocket tore through the blimp from end to end, obliterating $25 million of vital cameras and sensors. The explosion sounded like the sky itself was being ripped apart.

title: Ferrari CEO Resigns After Bout With Covid-19
summary: Mr. Camilleri, 65, took over Ferrari in 2018 after Sergio Marchionne died from complications linked to surgery. MILAN-Ferrari NV Chief Executive Louis Camilleri resigned unexpectedly from the Italian luxury sports-car maker after being hospitalized for Covid-19.

title: 'Happy Holidays' Is Pro-Christmas
summary: Advent and Epiphany are also holy days. Why not call them all what they are?. The season of good tidings often brings an awkward moment. It has happened in the checkout line, on a phone call, during a quick conversation with a neighbor. I'll say, "Merry Christmas." The other person will respond, "Happy holidays." Tranquility turns to tension. A simple exchange of well wishes ends uncomfortably.

title: Judge Sullivan's Final 'Verdict'
summary: A presidential pardon prompts a norm-busting outburst from the bench.. It's tempting to say that Judge Emmet Sullivan's final ruling in the Michael Flynn case reduced the judiciary to the level of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. But that would be unfair to today's law enforcement.

title: 'Brazil That Never Was' Review: His Own Private Amazon
summary: A British neurologist explores his passionate identiﬁcation with the reckless adventurer Percy Harrison Fawcett.. Like the late Oliver Sacks, Andrew Lees is a British neurologist who is also a talented writer of memoir, medical reportage and travelogue. Like Sacks, who died in 2015 at 82, Dr. Lees has made personal eccentricity into something of a cottage industry. A sense of oddness informs Dr. Lees's books, perhaps even more so than those of Sacks, whose signature volumes, such as "Awakenings" and "The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat," at least tempered their strange sensibility with mass-market appeal.

title: Notable & Quotable: Senate Snitching
summary: 'He installed a trusted former aide, Max Young, to 'embed' in the Judiciary Committee to make sure the hearings didn't go off the rails.'. Jane Mayerwriting for the New Yorker, Dec. 10:

title: Trump Bets on Long-Shot Texas Election Lawsuit
summary: Supreme Court is expected to decide quickly whether to allow Texas attorney general, 17 other Republican-leaning states and 106 GOP members of Congress to press claims. President Trump and his supporters have pinned their hopes of reversing President-elect Joe Biden's victory on a lawsuit filed by the Republican Texas attorney general that election-law specialists say has almost no chance of success.

title: Lululemon Gets Another Sales Bump From Cooped-Up Shoppers
summary: Comparable sales jumped 19%, driven by online shopping, amid continued demand for yoga pants and other at-home gear. Lululemon Athletica Inc. reported a big jump in sales and profits in the most recent quarter, as pandemic-weary shoppers snapped up its athletic apparel and other comfy gear, but it offered a less rosy prognosis for the year-end period as Covid-19 cases continue to surge.

title: The Best Books of 2020: Politics
summary: A diagnosis of entitlement culture, the story of populist radio and more of the year's standouts.. Christopher Caldwell's "The Age of Entitlement: America Since the Sixties" (Simon and Schuster, 352 pages, $28) appeared in January, before the George Floyd riots or the coronavirus panic, but a careful reader of this penetrating study of postwar America might have foreseen the reckless lunacy occasioned by both events. Mr. Caldwell contends that, with the passage and signing of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the nation's leaders established a new de facto constitution under which the purpose of politics was to remake civil society according to enlightened theories of racial justice. American leaders set about erecting enormously powerful and cripplingly expensive government agencies and programs to guarantee a state of racial equality. When their efforts failed, their successors created more such agencies and programs, and cultivated the destructive social convention known as political correctness to punish dissenters.

title: The Best Books of 2020: Children's Books
summary: From picture-book travels to fantastic adventures, a treasure-filled year of reading.. Four of the year's best picture books have waterways-real, metaphorical, man-made-that wind through them, taking young readers on empathetic journeys of imagination. In "Birrarung Wilam" (Candlewick, 40 pages, $17.99), the waterway is a real one, Australia's Yarra River, which gathers itself from tributaries far inland and runs through the city of Melbourne to the sea. The text of this exceptional book, by Aunty Joy Murphy and Andrew Kelly, has an incantatory magic, mingling English and the Aboriginal language of Woiwurrung: "As ngua rises, turning clouds over the distant city red . . . Birrarung begins its long winding path down to palem warreen." What do all these words mean? Children will be able to guess from what they see in Lisa Kennedy's evocative and rough-feeling paintings (see above). They can also check the glossary at the back. This is a marvel for reading aloud, a dreamlike sojourn through a distinctive riverine ecology.

title: The Best Books of 2020: Science Fiction
summary: From far-flung worlds to an eerie setting close to home, our columnist picks this year's stellar reading.. For sci-fi fans of a certain age, nothing was more welcome in 2020 than Eric Flint and Dave Freer's "The Shaman of Karres" (Baen, 292 pages, $25), the third sequel to James H. Schmitz's "The Witches of Karres," now 70 years old and still a candidate for the best space-opera ever. "Shaman" follows the adventures of the Leewit, the youngest of the witches, whirling through space with hapless Captain Pausert on the trail of a new alien threat, one worse than the Megair Cannibals or the nanite menace. This time it's a strange creature with powers of mind control, so insidious the controlled don't even notice. Pure fun from the past, with just a touch of satire, all updated and with added invention. Who can resist the Daal of Uldune, a six-clone hexaperson, who is also a ruthless tyrant trying to go straight? Until, that is, his chivalrous instincts are stimulated and the gloves come off.

title: The Best Books of 2020: Mysteries
summary: A thriller of World War II Paris, the return of Inspector Gamache and more of the year in crime fiction.. Cara Black has earned a loyal following with her series starring Parisian investigator Aimée Leduc. This year, Ms. Black showed a new facet of her talent with the historical thriller "Three Hours in Paris" (Soho Crime 348 pages, $27.95). It's the ticking-clock saga of Kate Rees, a sharpshooting American war widow trained by the British and smuggled into Paris in 1940 to assassinate the leader of Nazi Germany. The reader assumes Kate will miss her shot at Adolf Hitler-this is not alternative history-but what surprises is what comes next. Kate makes contact with Resistance operatives in a race to elude a German policeman tasked by the Führer himself with her swift capture.

title: Biden Names Susan Rice to Lead Domestic Policy Council
summary: President-elect tasks Obama-era veteran with mapping his agenda on issues including health care and climate change. WASHINGTON-President-elect Joe Biden has chosen Susan Rice, a former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, to lead the White House Domestic Policy Council, as he fills out his government with veterans of the Obama administration.

title: 'Doomscrolling': The New, High-Tech Way to Slide Into Despair
summary: The impulse to constantly check phone screens for bad news only got its name in the last few years. Linguist and lexicographer Ben Zimmer analyzes the origins of words in the news. Read previous columns here.

title: Break Up Facebook? It's Complicated, Tech Experts Say
summary: Splitting off Instagram and WhatsApp potentially would involve years of engineering and legal work. Breaking up Facebook Inc. would be difficult and expensive, but not impossible, according to current and former employees along with tech-industry experts.

title: U.S. Sanctions Accused Human Rights Abusers in Several Countries
summary: Russian, Chinese, Houthi officials and former officials among figures earning U.S. reproval. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration on Thursday sanctioned dozens of current and former foreign officials accused of political repression through killings, torture, rape and other human rights abuses in Russia, China, Yemen and other nations.

title: Top CEOs Back Push to Create One Million Jobs for Black Americans
summary: The leaders of companies including Nike, Merck and IBM are backing a startup called OneTen, which aims to create the jobs in the next 10 years. More than 30 chief executive officers from companies including Merck & Co., International Business Machines Corp. and Nike Inc. are backing a new nonprofit startup called OneTen, which will focus on training Black candidates for corporate roles. Black people make up 12.4% of the U.S. population, but 8% of professionals, a number that has stayed steady since 2013, according to a study by the nonprofit research group the Center for Talent Innovation.

title: Israel and Morocco Agree to Normalize Relations
summary: Deal required U.S. recognition of Moroccan sovereignty over disputed Western Sahara. Israel and Morocco agreed to normalize relations, President Trump and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Thursday, marking another advance in U.S. efforts to strengthen ties between once-hostile nations in the region.

title: Joseph Safra, Banking Empire Founder and Brazil's Richest Man, Has Died
summary: The Safra brothers built up banks in Latin America, New York and Switzerland that catered discreetly to ultrarich clients. SÃO PAULO-Joseph Safra, a Lebanese-Brazilian billionaire who built an international financial empire and financed a hostile takeover of Chiquita Brands International that took the business world by surprise, died Thursday here in Brazil's business capital. He was 82.

title: Gov. Jindal, Health-Care Policy and the GOP
summary: Expand the choices.. Bobby Jindal is correct in "Can GOP Find Its Way on Health Care?" (op-ed, Dec. 3). The goal of a Republican plan should be to provide any person who is sick or injured with the appropriate care in the appropriate setting at the appropriate time in the management of any illness or injury, with emphasis on preventing illness or injury whenever possible. This will take away the one central issue on which the Democrats have held the advantage, access to care.

title: Consider Student Loans as Any Investment
summary: The only thing that hits parents harder than college-loan debt is sacrificing for 20 years to avoid borrowing in the first place.. In response to "College-Loan Debt Hits Parents Hard" (Page One, Dec. 3): There are many families that have saved for years and subsequently sent their children to colleges within their means. The only thing that hits parents harder than college-loan debt is sacrificing for 20 years to avoid borrowing in the first place.

title: U.S. Stocks Wobble as Economic Picture Dims
summary: Jobless claims jumped sharply last week, fresh data showed Thursday. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones Industrial Average drifted lower Thursday, pulled down by broad losses that offset a rally in the energy sector.

title: Lebanon Leader Charged With Negligence for Beirut Explosion
summary: Judge investigating deadly blast at port charges Hassan Diab and three former ministers. The Lebanese judge leading an investigation into the massive explosion at Beirut's port charged the caretaker prime minister and three former ministers with negligence that resulted in the destruction of a swath of the capital and nearly 200 deaths in August.

title: Airbnb's Stock Price More Than Doubles in Market Debut
summary: IPO ends difficult year for the home-sharing company, which has had to readjust its business amid travel downturn because of Covid-19. Airbnb Inc.'s shares more than doubled in their trading debut on Thursday, reflecting a soaring market for new stock listings and the home-sharing company's ability to navigate the coronavirus-induced downturn in travel this year.

title: Risky Business (Friday Crossword, December 11)
Whitney Cummings on Stand-Up Comedy in 2020 and Beyond
summary: It has been a very weird year, she says. But stand-up is going to come back stronger than ever.. Four questions with Whitney Cummings, stand-up comic, actress and host of the "Good For You" podcast.

title: Brazil to Allow Vaccine Makers to Seek Emergency Authorization
summary: The move by the Anvisa health authority comes as states try to secure vaccines themselves. SÃO PAULO-Brazil's health authority Anvisa said Thursday it would allow producers of Covid-19 vaccines to request emergency authorization in the country, raising hopes that the hard-hit nation can begin its immunization rollout as early as this month.

title: Bestselling Books Week Ended December 5
summary: With data from NPD BookScan.

title: LinkedIn Starts Testing Ads in 'Stories'
summary: The professional-networking platform wants users and brands to adopt a format known for its casual, personal nature. LinkedIn has begun testing advertisements within its fledgling "stories" format in the U.S. and Canada as the Microsoft Corp. -owned professional networking platform seeks to boost ad revenue.

title: Macron's Secular Solution Isn't Working With Islam
summary: A more promising path for integrating Islam into French society is the laïcité positive advocated by former president Nicolas Sarkozy.. While Christopher Caldwell has outlined the rigid secularism of President Emmanuel Macron ("Macron Seeks an Enlightened Islam," Houses of Worship, Dec. 4), a more promising path for integrating Islam into French society is the laïcité positive advocated by former President Nicolas Sarkozy. Mr. Sarkozy insisted, to the surprise of his contemporaries, that religion must have some serious role in French society. His endorsement was strongly seconded by Pope Benedict XVI who both in France and the U.S. spoke of a "healthy secularism," one in which the government, while always maintaining its autonomy, recognized the spiritual and transcendent dimension of humanity. Failing such recognition, Islam will remain a polarizing and unassimilated element within French society.

title: Corporate America's Borrowing Binge May Be Ending
summary: Net new supply of new bonds could hit the lowest level since 2002 next year-a potential headache for bond fund managers. The record corporate borrowing boom fueled by the Federal Reserve's pandemic response may be coming to an end. Wall Street bankers and investors are preparing for a sharp drop in corporate bond sales next year.

title: The GOP Abandoned Fiscal Discipline Long, Long Ago
summary: The redistributionists on the right long ago lost the ability to cry foul over spending.. It is quite comical that Kimberley Strassel believes that Republicans should suddenly have the discipline to "unite around a bedrock conservative principle: fiscal discipline" ("McConnell's Spending Line," Potomac Watch, Dec. 4). Donald Trump and Senate Republicans increased the debt by $6.7 trillion over the last four years. To put that in perspective, the Obama administration increased the debt by $8.6 trillion over eight years. In real dollar terms, the last four years saw the greatest spending increase in U.S. history. In other words, apart from perhaps Rand Paul, the redistributionists on the right long ago lost the ability to cry foul over spending.

title: Amazon Wants to Train 29 Million People to Work in the Cloud
summary: New programs seek to help people from Montana to Nigeria attain roles ranging from tech support to machine learning. Amazon . com Inc. announced an effort Thursday aimed at helping 29 million people world-wide retrain by 2025, giving them new skills for cloud-computing roles as the pandemic upends many careers.

title: ECB Expands Stimulus Program to Prop Up Pandemic-Hit Economy
summary: Central bank's decision underscores the bumpy path ahead for the eurozone economy. FRANKFURT-The European Central Bank scaled up its emergency bond-buying program by more than a third and unveiled a new batch of ultracheap loans for banks, a bold stimulus package aimed at backstopping the region's governments and businesses as they navigate a stubborn resurgence of the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Boris Johnson Warns Brexit Talks Could Fail as EU Sets No-Deal Plans
summary: British prime minister's warning comes as bloc sets out proposed terms to ease expected travel delays. BRUSSELS-British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said there was a strong possibility that negotiations over a new trade agreement with the European Union would fail as the European Commission set out contingency plans to maintain basic rail, air and freight links between the U.K. and the bloc in case talks collapse.

title: Many Biden Cabinet Picks Are Veterans of Obama Administration
summary: President-elect taps officials with experience in last Democratic White House. President-elect Joe Biden has chosen to fill a number of posts in his administration with people who served under President Barack Obama. Here is a list of the people he has picked who also worked in the last Democratic administration.

title: Smarter Cars: Auto Makers Experiment With Chips That Think Like Humans
summary: Mercedes-Benz is exploring how neuromorphic chips could bring new AI capabilities to its vehicles. Experimental computer chips that try to mimic the way human brains work could accelerate the use of voice and gesture commands in automobiles, researchers at Intel Corp. and Accenture PLC say.

title: Airbnb's IPO: Stock Price, Valuation and Everything Else You Need to Know
summary: The home-sharing giant's stock more than doubled in its market debut. Here's what to know about the newly minted public company.. Home-sharing giant Airbnb Inc.'s stock more than doubled in its market debut, reflecting strong demand for the shares despite a challenging year when the travel industry buckled under the coronavirus pandemic.

title: New York City to Gauge Students' Learning Loss During Pandemic
summary: Mayor Bill de Blasio says district will assess the impact of Covid-19 school closures. New York City plans to administer new low-stakes assessments to public-school students to gauge the depth of learning loss from trauma and school closures during the Covid-19 pandemic, officials said Thursday.

title: Steven Soderbergh on 'Let Them All Talk' and Future of Movie Theaters
summary: The Oscar-winning director and writer discusses Covid, collages and why anyone with an iPhone can be in the film business. NO FILM BUDGET is too high or too low to spook Steven Soderbergh, who's spent decades crafting everything from indie classics like "sex, lies, and videotape" to award-winning dramas like "Traffic" and blockbusters like "Ocean's Eleven." All he asks: that the shoots be frightening in interesting ways.

title: House Leaders Clash Over Swalwell's Role in China Spy Probe
summary: Pelosi defends California Democratic lawmaker from McCarthy's criticism; no accusation of wrongdoing. House GOP leader Kevin McCarthy called for Rep. Eric Swalwell to be removed from office over allegations that the lawmaker was targeted by a suspected Chinese spy, prompting House Speaker Nancy Pelosi to rise to the defense of her fellow California Democrat.

title: Brent Crude Rises Above $50 as Oil's Turnaround Continues
summary: Thursday's advance continues a monthslong rebound from oil's April lows around $19 a barrel during global economic shutdowns. Brent crude prices topped $50 a barrel for the first time since early March on Thursday, the latest milestone in a remarkable oil-market recovery fueled by supply curtailments and drivers returning to the road.

title: 'The Midnight Sky': Reaching Out in the Void
summary: George Clooney directs and stars in this post-apocalypic saga that intertwines the stories of an Arctic researcher, returning astronauts, and a mysterious little girl.. Toward the end of "The Midnight Sky"-a haunting post-apocalyptic adventure starring George Clooney, who directed, and Felicity Jones-astronauts aboard a space ship that's been forced to change course discuss using the slingshot effect, getting a boost in velocity from the gravitational field of a planet, in this case Earth. The film, showing in select theaters before its debut on Netflix later this month, gets a boost from the gravity of Earth's plight. In the past it was easier to see end-of-civilization sagas as entertainment. Now, at a time when the United Nations secretary-general has called the state of our planet "broken," a movie like this one hits closer to home. That's not to suggest it is nothing more than a cautionary tale. Mr. Clooney and his colleagues have crafted an elegant screen version of a novel by Lily Brooks-Dalton with a resonant performance at its center-his own.

title: 'Heroes of the Fourth Turning' Review: A Culture-War Conversation Piece
summary: In Will Arbery's singular, sympathetic play, young conservative intellectuals gather to discuss their post-graduate lives and political concerns in the age of Trump.. Will Arbery's "Heroes of the Fourth Turning" was one of the most talked-about plays of 2019, and I fully intended to review Playwrights Horizons' New York premiere in this space. Unfortunately, a family crisis made it impossible for me to do so, and the coming of the pandemic subsequently prevented regional theaters from taking up the play. I've been crossing my fingers ever since that somebody out there would mount a webcast version. Now Philadelphia's Wilma Theater, one of the East Coast's leading drama companies, has taped a fully staged site-specific production of "Heroes of the Fourth Turning" at a private location in the Poconos, turning the cast and crew into a closed quarantine "bubble" so that they could work together face-to-face instead of taping their performances separately via Zoom or green screens. The result, which looks more like a small-scale movie than an online webcast of a stage show, is a flawless, impressively well-cast production of a work of singular distinction, one for which the word "remarkable" is, if anything, an understatement.

title: U.S. Household Net Worth Hits Record in Third Quarter
summary: Household net worth grew to $123.52 trillion, according to Fed's Flow of Funds report, as growth in household debt rose 5.6%. The net worth of U.S. households rose to a record in the third quarter as the value of stock portfolios and real estate surged, a Federal Reserve report showed, highlighting the skewed nature of an economic recovery that has disproportionately benefited wealthier Americans.

title: CFTC Chairman Tarbert to Resign, Remain at the Derivatives Regulator
summary: Republicans could retain control of the commission until 2022, despite transfer of power in the White House. The head of the nation's derivatives regulator will step down from his leadership role while remaining a commissioner, leaving control of the five-person panel in Republican hands, at least for now.

title: House Panel Accuses Trump Administration of Concealing Evidence in CDC Coronavirus Probe
summary: Senior official tells subcommittee she was told to delete email showing political meddling in key report. The chairman of a Democratic-led House oversight subcommittee accused the Trump administration of concealing evidence based on the testimony of a career employee at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, who said political appointees interfered in the agency's work to fight the coronavirus pandemic.

title: 'Let Them All Talk' Review: Celebs Adrift
summary: Steven Soderbergh's microbudget, improvised comedy about old friends reuniting on a trans-Atlantic cruise stars Meryl Streep, Candice Bergen and Dianne Wiest.. Making a studio feature can be arduous- relentless pressure, constant script revisions, the deployment of vast technical resources, the tyranny of marketing strategies. Any actor who values artistic freedom would jump at the chance to make a movie almost spontaneously, which is the way the HBO Max comedy "Let Them All Talk" was made, and to make it with Steven Soderbergh, a filmmaker with a special affinity for directing actors. And look who did jump: Meryl Streep, Candice Bergen and Dianne Wiest, three legends of our time. Mr. Soderbergh, serving as his own cinematographer, shot the film in two weeks on a microbudget; the main location was the luxury liner Queen Mary 2 during a trans-Atlantic crossing So how did such an adventurous production turn out? Not very well, though it's certainly a curiosity, a chance to see what happens when superb performers improvise their lines in the absence of a conventional script.

title: 'Total Control' Review: A Struggle Down Under
summary: Conflicts over political power and indigenous rights lie at the center of Sundance Now's new drama.. The physical and social backgrounds essential to this dark political tale exert their powers early. "Total Control" (begins Thursday, Dec. 17, Sundance Now) is a six-part drama set in the Australian Outback. A place, we're shown, where people spend their days swatting at the flies circling their heads, and where conversation is dry and to the point, and jokey, though without cruelty. It's the way of this society to be wary of strangers but not impossibly so, as one government representative discovers in episode 1, when he comes knocking on the door of a house in the small town of Winton. He's met with suspicion by the woman who opens it-she quickly decides he's a Mormon, seeking converts, and informs him that he's wasting his time.

title: 'Gunda' Review: A Pig's Life
summary: Victor Kossakovsky's documentary takes a sow as its subject to tell the story of agriculture and industrial farming.. The star of Victor Kossakovsky's "Gunda" is a pig. Gunda is her name, and lactating is her game; she's a mammary mountain with what I counted to be 10 piglets on her slope. I had time to count piglets, and reflect on their lives and fate, because time flows slowly in this one-of-a-kind documentary feature, shot in luminous, almost magical-realist, black and white. It would flow at a turtle's pace if the cast included turtles, but there's only Gunda and her brood, plus a one-legged chicken who hops around a field with surprising grace and a small herd of cows, seemingly happy-or at least not unhappy-to be standing or sitting in the rain. These creatures are in no rush either. Watching them, you get some sense of their life rhythms while readjusting your own.

title: VA Secretary Wilkie Mishandled Sex-Assault Claim, Report Finds
summary: Monthslong investigation finds the secretary disparaged the woman making the allegation. Veterans Affairs Secretary Robert Wilkie mishandled an investigation into sexual assault at the department and disparaged the woman making the claim, according to a report released by the VA Office of Inspector General.

title: Mnuchin Defends Coronavirus-Relief Loan to Troubled Trucking Firm YRC
summary: Treasury secretary said taxpayers will get their money back. WASHINGTON-Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin defended the government's decision to lend $700 million in coronavirus-relief funds to trucking firm YRC Worldwide Inc., telling a congressional oversight panel Thursday that taxpayers will profit from the loan.

title: U.S. Budget Gap Widened 25% in Two Months of Fiscal Year
summary: Higher spending, shrinking revenue tied to the pandemic and resulting economic downturn pushed deficit higher. The U.S. budget deficit widened 25% in October and November from the same period last year to $429 billion, a record for the first two months of the fiscal year, the Treasury Department said Thursday.

title: Taylor Swift's New Album 'Evermore' Embraces 'More Is More' Release Strategy
summary: The pop star's ninth studio album, due at midnight Friday, is her second surprise release of 2020. For Taylor Swift fans, Christmas is coming early: Ms. Swift on Thursday announced her ninth studio album, "Evermore," which is the second unexpected release of the year for one of music's most notoriously meticulous pop stars.

title: The Bidens and Beijing
summary: Tax questions about Hunter's income raise again the question of how he earned it.. Hunter Biden may have wanted to hold 10% for the "big guy," but did he forget to set aside 37% for Uncle Sam? A tax investigation focused on the Biden family's highly questionable sources of income may finally force them to answer precisely how such income is generated in the first place.

title: MassMutual Joins the Bitcoin Club With $100 Million Purchase
summary: Investment is latest sign of mainstream acceptance for upstart digital currency. Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Co. bought $100 million of bitcoin for its general investment account, the latest sign of mainstream acceptance for the upstart digital currency.

title: Jobless Claims Rise Sharply
summary: Labor-market recovery appears to be cooling; consumer prices edge higher in November. The economic recovery has downshifted, with job growth slowing and layoffs persisting at a high level amid rising coronavirus cases and related restrictions.

title: For One California Couple, Their New Tahoe Home Served as an 'Antidote to L.A.'
summary: Wes and Julie Nichols used wood and ebonized steel to help their Truckee house blend into its surroundings. When Wes and Julie Nichols set out to build a new house in Truckee, Calif., they sought more than just a nice view of trees. Their goal was an immersive experience-to evoke the sense of walking deep in an untouched forest as light filters through branches in cool greens and rough browns, the smell of pine all around.

title: Cigna Promotes Company Veteran to CFO Role
summary: Brian Evanko is set to become the health-care company's finance chief on Jan. 1. Cigna Corp. promoted a company veteran to chief finance officer, part of a wider management reshuffle at the health-care services company.

title: U.K. Allows Banks to Resume Dividend Payments
summary: Regulator says it isn't necessary to extend precautionary action taken as the pandemic began. U.K. banks can resume paying dividends next year after regulators ended a ban introduced in March to make lenders conserve capital during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: The Shah, the Mullahs and Iran's Longstanding Nuclear Ambitions
summary: For five decades, under two very different regimes, Tehran has built up the infrastructure for a bomb but stopped short of making one. Iran's nuclear ambitions are again looming over a new American administration. President-elect Joe Biden has pledged to resuscitate the 2015 Iran nuclear deal that President Trump unilaterally discarded. But after four years of enduring sanctions and targeted assassinations, the Islamic Republic may no longer be listening. Some experts fear that Iran's pragmatists-led by President Hassan Rouhani, who negotiated the nuclear agreement-have been discredited and that Iran's hard-liners are too suspicious of the West to reengage with another American leader.

title: Team USA Backs Allowing Athlete Protests at Olympics
summary: U.S. Olympic leaders say they won't punish athletes who advocate for racial and social justice at the Games. The International Olympic Committee bans such displays.. Olympic officials banished two American track athletes from the 1968 Summer Games for protesting racial injustice by raising black-gloved fists on the medal stand. On Thursday, Team USA signaled that it believes such a punishment shouldn't happen again.

title: How Many People Have Had Covid-19 Across the U.S.?
summary: A state-by-state breakdown of America's 15 million confirmed coronavirus cases. The latest Covid-19 surge in the U.S. has left few corners of the country untouched. And with more than 100,000 cases reported each day for the past month, the chances of encountering someone who has contracted the virus are increasing.

title: Two Canadians Held in China Haven't Been Tried, Contrary to Reports
summary: A Chinese briefing sparked news stories, but Canada says the status of Michael Kovrig and Michael Spavor is unchanged. title: Online Seafood Buying Guide: Where the Chefs Shop
summary: These purveyors' websites will deliver restaurant-quality seafood direct to the rest of us. THERE'S NEVER been a better time to buy seafood online. title: New York Cultural Scene Increasingly Draws Immigrant Artists
summary: But a new report warns that Covid-19 pandemic could stymie the growing population. New York City is home to a sizable and ever-growing population of artists from abroad, according to a new report. But they face myriad challenges, particularly during the coronavirus pandemic, that may affect their ability to continue working and living within the five boroughs, the study notes.

title: Facebook's Profile Will Change, Win or Lose

title: There's More to Politics Than Policy
summary: There's no substitute for finding candidates who capture voters' hearts. No, not even a 30-point plan.. It is tempting to treat elections as math problems, while ignoring the art required to assemble winning coalitions. Pollsters sort data along demographic groupings, data analysts dissect precinct-level trends, and ad makers consult focus groups to craft appealing messages. The result is policies designed to appeal to enough voters to win, presented by disciplined politicians in sound bites that are repeated relentlessly.

title: Biden Can Make American Trade Deals Great Again
summary: Unions might resist, but most Democrats now agree that economic isolation is a losing proposition.. President-elect Joe Biden probably wishes he could avoid trade policy. He can't. To re-establish partnerships with allies, devise rules for a changing world economy, and prepare the American labor force for the future, Mr. Biden will have to defuse Donald Trump's trade wars and connect his economic and foreign policies. The press reported on Wednesday that Mr. Biden will nominate Katherine Tai, a talented trade lawyer with experience in Congress, to be U.S. Trade Representative. Ms. Tai has an opportunity to reshape policy and realign trade politics.

title: Model Mona Tougaard on the Challenges of Being Multiracial on the Runway
summary: The newest catwalk star on her Danish, Somali, Ethiopian and Turkish background and the progress that the fashion industry still needs to make. Model Mona Tougaard, the youngest of three children, was just 9 when her mother died. "Life is something that can get taken away. You have to live it fully and do whatever makes you happy," says Tougaard, 18, who was raised by her father in Aarhus, Denmark. "He's my best friend," she says.

title: How Covid-19 Changed Movies in 2020
summary: As the coronavirus shuttered cinemas, first-run films moved online, and while home-viewing might not equal a packed theater, there were still plenty of standout movies to see.. I remember the days. Of driving off to screening rooms and watching movies on big screens. Of going to multiplexes around town for previews of action adventures on enormous screens. Plenty of new movies have been released for streaming since the Covid-19 pandemic shut down theaters in March. Obviously, though, it hasn't been the same. There's a gnawing sense of loss for movie lovers. Of the spectacle that was usually pleasurable, even if the substance wasn't so great. Of the nourishing ritual-not the popcorn or Milk Duds, though they were swell too, but the social ritual of sitting in the dark and sharing movies with people you did and didn't know. (This is not the time to dwell on negatives like sticky floors and spectators chattering on their cellphones.)

title: Whale Watching in New York Grows More Common

title: The Best Face Masks for Kids-According to Kids
summary: Four outspoken children on their favorite face coverings, including styles peppered with Star Wars space ships and pliéing ballerinas. WHEN IT comes to masks, children have specific needs. While you might covet that chic Clare V. animal-print style, it might not suit your fidgety 5-year-old's style-or her head size. We asked four kids across the country to hold forth on their favorite face-coverings, and how adults can ensure the masks they buy their own children won't end up "lost" to the depths of the back seat. Some takeaways: Find a whimsical pattern that reflects your child's interests. Avoid fussy behind-the-head straps and look for ear loops made of softer, stretchier materials. Below, more pandemic wisdom from the single-digit set.

summary: Napoleon stayed here. So did Charles Dickens. But it's the four-legged residents-generations of St. Bernards-that have made this monastery and inn one of the most intriguing destinations in the Alps. Even if you have to reach it by snowshoe.. For the Time Capsule series, we spotlight a cherished restaurant, hotel or landmark that's changed remarkably little over the years. This week, we visit Great St. Bernard Hospice in Switzerland.

title: Adam Gerhart Named Global CEO of Media Agency Mindshare
summary: The WPP media agency giant fired Nick Emery, Mindshare's longtime CEO, in October. WPP PLC ad-buying unit GroupM named Adam Gerhart global chief executive of its Mindshare agency, filling an opening created when former global CEO Nick Emery was fired nearly two months ago.

title: Nature's Guide to Building Resilient Systems
summary: To cope with unpredictable challenges, human institutions can adapt the strategies used by leaves, bees and Earth's atmosphere.. Most people are looking forward to the end of 2020, which brought us the Covid-19 pandemic, raging fires in the American West, the most active hurricane season on record, social unrest and political rancor. But this year has also taught us an important lesson: Human institutions have difficulty coping with unpredictable events. Governments and businesses know how to plan for familiar challenges in the short term, but we need new tools for dealing with surprises that catch society off-guard-especially since epidemics and natural disasters are sure to become more common in the coming decades, thanks to globalization and climate change.

title: Ethiopia: What We Know About the War in the Tigray Region
summary: Conflict in the north of Africa's second-most-populous nation is spreading across borders, threatening stability in a strategic region. Long-simmering tensions between Ethiopia's federal government, led by Nobel Peace Prize-winning Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed, and defiant authorities in its northern Tigray region have erupted into a military confrontation. Hundreds of civilians have died, while tens of thousands have sought refuge in Sudan from airstrikes, as the conflict threatens to further destabilize the strategic Horn of Africa region.

title: Will Coronavirus Be the Death of Cities? Not So Fast
summary: An urban expert on how the pandemic will give us a once-in-a-century opportunity to reinvent our cities, suburbs and rural areas. The Covid-19 crisis is bringing a Great Reset to our cities, suburbs and communities. Not just the health crisis-the economic and fiscal crises emerging in its wake, and the wave of protests for racial and economic justice that has swept up alongside it, are altering the way we live and work in powerful ways. This Great Urban Reset gives us a once-in-a-century opportunity to create more equitable and inclusive communities of all sizes and shapes.

title: Missed Tesla's 12,551% Rise? Don't Feel So Bad

The electric-car company is up 12,551% since the close on the day of its 2010 IPO, enough to turn a modest $10,000 holding into a $1.3 million luxury beach house. title: The Bold Future of Caviar
summary: The next step toward sustainable caviar involves harvesting eggs without killing the sturgeon. In 2021, pending FDA approval, California Caviar Company will bring to market North America's first domestic caviar made without slaughtering the sturgeon that produced it. The method comprises massaging mature eggs from mature sturgeons' bellies, then stabilizing the eggs in a calcium bath so they retain their pearl-like texture while releasing the fish back into the water. The process was invented by marine biologist Angela Köhler to make farming sturgeon more economically appealing, thereby undermining poaching of wild sturgeon, many species of which are officially listed as endangered. "If the caviar will be available [at] a reasonable price, it doesn't make any sense anymore to catch wild sturgeon," says Köhler, whose former employer, Germany's Alfred Wegener Institute for Polar and Marine Research, holds the patent for her method.
